required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Men's Beliefs About Associations Between HPV, Cancers, and HPV Vaccination
clinical_study.official_title: Men's Beliefs About Associations Between HPV, Cancers, and HPV Vaccination

lead_sponsor.agency: University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill

clinical_study.source: University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill

brief_summary.textblock: This research focuses on men who have sex with men (MSM) who are at higher risk of anal cancer. The survey will evaluate their beliefs about anal and oral cancer, their knowledge about role of human papillomavirus (HPV) infection in these cancers, and their knowledge of HPV vaccination and anal Pap smears. Approximately 12% of subjects will be HIV-positive.

detailed_description.textblock: Little research has examined men's understanding of what causes anal and oral cancers and whether HPV vaccination can play a potential protective role. This research focuses on men who have sex with men (MSM) who are at notably elevated risk of anal cancer, and seeks to characterize their beliefs about anal and oral cancer, knowledge about the etiological role of HPV infection in these cancers, as well as their knowledge of HPV vaccination and anal Pap smears. We will also study heterosexual men.

primary_outcome.measure: Willingness to Receive the Human Papillomavirus (HPV) Vaccine
primary_outcome.description: Measured participants' willingness to receive HPV vaccine. Participants were asked how willing they would be to get HPV vaccine if it were approved for use in males. A 5-point scale ranging from "definitely not willing" to "definitely willing" was used to meausure willingness.

secondary_outcome.description: Measured if participants had heard of HPV vaccine prior to survey. Participants were asked if they had heard to HPV vaccine prior to the survey and had response options of "yes", "no", and "I don't know".

Assessed participants' knowledge of HPV by summing correct responses to nine HPV knowledge items. Questions addressed what diseases are associated with HPV, how HPV is transmitted, and how common HPV infection is. For each item, participants were classified as having answered the item correctly or incorrectly.

study_pop.textblock: Approximately 600 men (ages 18-59) who have agreed to participate in a periodic panel through the private survey company, Knowledge Networks.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- male
- aged 18-59
- answered question about sexual orientation
Exclusion Criteria:

overall_official.affiliation: The University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, School of Public Health

participant_flow.recruitment_details: Data was collected for this cross-sectional study through an online survey. Of the 874 men invited to participate, 609 (70%) completed the online survey. A pilot test was conducted between December 29, 2008 and January 4, 2009, and the main survey was conducted between January 6, 2009 and January 26, 2009.

group.title: Study Participants
group.description: All study participants, this observational study was not a trial that involved multiple arms

outcome.title: Willingness to Receive the Human Papillomavirus (HPV) Vaccine
outcome.description: Measured participants' willingness to receive HPV vaccine. Participants were asked how willing they would be to get HPV vaccine if it were approved for use in males. A 5-point scale ranging from "definitely not willing" to "definitely willing" was used to meausure willingness.
outcome.population: One man reported having received human papillomavirus (HPV) vaccine so he was not asked willingness items which made the analytic sample size n=608

certain_agreements.pi_employee: Principal Investigators are NOT employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: The only disclosure restriction on the PI is that the sponsor can review results communications prior to public release and can embargo communications regarding trial results for a period that is less than or equal to 60 days. The sponsor cannot require changes to the communication and cannot extend the embargo.

point_of_contact.organization: The University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, Gillings School of Global Public Health
